image.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: US: 2 shot dead, nine injured in separate shootings in New Orleans
item.description: Two separate shootings disrupted a "second line" parade in New Orleans' St Roch neighborhood, claiming the lives of two individuals and leaving nine others injured. The incidents, occurring 45 minutes apart, transpired along the parade route, marring the traditional celebratory event with violence.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Joe Biden allows Ukraine to use long-range US missiles for first time against Russia
item.description: President Biden has authorized the transfer of long-range ATACMS missiles to Ukraine for use against Russian targets. This decision follows a massive Russian missile and drone attack on Ukrainian civilian infrastructure. Zelenskyy, while condemning the attacks and Russia's collaboration with North Korea, urged the G20 for a decisive response to deter further aggression.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 8 killed as Russia launches one of its fiercest missile and drone attacks at Ukraine's infrastructure
Most complaints exaggerated: Muhammad Yunus denies widespread violence against Hindus in Bangladesh
Trump's defence secretary pick paid an accuser, but denies sex assault
Muhammad Yunus promises polls after reforms
Thomas E Kurtz, a creator of BASIC computer language, dies at 96
60 years after Malcolm X killing, daughters sue FBI, CIA, NYPD
'Super year' of elections was 'super bad' for incumbents
In a policy shift, Biden allows Ukraine to hit Russia with long-range US missiles
'Hate isn't welcome': Neo-Nazis march with Swastika flags in Ohio, 'Trump's America' stunned
item.description: A group of individuals wearing masks and carrying Nazi flags marched through the Short North area of Columbus, Ohio, prompting strong condemnation from officials. Although some individuals were briefly detained, no arrests were made. Governor Mike DeWine and the City of Columbus issued statements denouncing the display of hate and affirming their commitment to protecting all residents.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Oklahoma superintendent Ryan Walters faces criticism over religious freedom video mandate in schools
item.description: Oklahoma's education superintendent, Ryan Walters, is facing backlash for mandating schools to show a video promoting his new Department of Religious Freedom and Patriotism. The video includes a prayer for Donald Trump and his team. Critics, including the state attorney general, argue that Walters lacks the authority for this mandate and that it infringes on parents' rights and religious freedom.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Prince William and Kate Middleton consider Lady Louise, the Duke of Edinburgh's daughter, a 'royal asset'
item.description: Lady Louise Windsor, niece of King Charles, is admired by the Prince and Princess of Wales for her down-to-earth upbringing and potential as a working royal. Despite having the option to use HRH titles, Louise and her brother were raised with the expectation of pursuing careers.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Hezbollah media chief Mohammed Afif al-Naboulsi killed in Israeli strike on Beirut
item.description: Tensions escalate in the Middle East as Israel conducts airstrikes in Beirut and Gaza, resulting in numerous casualties. Hezbollah's chief spokesman was killed in a targeted strike, prompting retaliatory rocket fire into Israel. The strikes come as ceasefire negotiations are underway, with Lebanon accusing Israel of escalating violence.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: New York Archdiocese lays off workers to reduce financial strain from sex-abuse scandal
item.description: The Archdiocese of New York is laying off 18 administrative staff members, aiming to save over $1.5 million annually. The decision comes amidst financial difficulties, partly attributed to the ongoing sex abuse scandal and upcoming relocation to a smaller office.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Poll guru Nate Silver says Donald Trump's win is Biden's fault: 'Kamala got tough assignments'
item.description: Nate Silver said Harris's campaign comprising mostly ex-Biden people was reluctant to criticize Biden "out of fear of being perceived as disloyal" but Biden frequently undermined her. Silver wrote Kamala Harris has plenty of talent and sometimes and sometimes, replacement-level talent is good enough in a pinch. But this was a difficult electoral environment for Democrats.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Florida woman using mother's identity for hurricane aid blames 'botox' for younger look, gets arrested
item.description: Florida resident Veronica Torres, 44, was apprehended for allegedly impersonating her mother to secure hurricane relief funds. Torres allegedly utilized her mother's identification to fraudulently obtain a check for $7,967, claiming hurricane-related displacement. When confronted about an age discrepancy, Torres attributed her youthful appearance to "botox treatments." She was subsequently arrested and charged with filing a false public assistance claim.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Amid Net censorship, Pakistan offers regulated VPNs
item.description: Pakistan's Telecommunication Authority initiated a registration process for VPNs following a nationwide ban on unregistered ones. The government claims the ban targets militant groups, but critics view it as an attempt to stifle dissent amidst online criticism of the military and the blocking of platforms like X.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Dirty little secret is...': Vivek Ramaswamy on which departments he and Elon Musk will ax first
item.description: Vivek Ramaswamy, co-leader of the Department of Government Efficiency, announced plans to drastically reduce the federal bureaucracy, including potentially eliminating entire agencies. Ramaswamy said a lot of federal staff will lose their jobs because the bureaucrats in Washington do not even work five days a week like the maximum hardworking Americans and the government do not need so many bureaucrats who are unelected.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US pollster J Ann Selzer retires after Iowa poll inaccurately predicted Harris ahead of Trump
item.description: Veteran US pollster J Ann Selzer announced her retirement from election polling after her final Iowa Poll incorrectly predicted the 2024 presidential election outcome. Despite a long history of accuracy, the poll significantly misjudged the result, prompting Selzer to step down and the Des Moines Register to revamp its polling methodology.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
